Gordon's Budget
Lincoln Gordon did what many skeptical professors
said he couldn't: he drastically cut the very
administration he had overexpanded in the past four
years. But, unfortunately, the President only went as far
as the faculty technically requested. As stated by a
number of professors, he ignored the "spirit" of the
resolution by cutting his immediate administration ten
per cent but his supporting administration (when
totaled together) zero per cent.
Many professors claim that the library, registrar's
office and plant maintenance will still spend too much
next year. They cite the figure, for example, that the
library spends over $1 million in salaries and $300,000 on
the acquisition of new books. On the other hand the
Provost asserts that the library is a two-shift-a-day,
seven-day-a-week enterprise requiring a tremendous
amount of manpower. It is still too early to tell if the
library and other support services need to be trimmed.
But one fact, little discussed at the faculty meeting,
stands clear: the President has not done all he can to
raise money. The 1976 Centennial Capital Campaign,
which was supposed to begin this winter, has been
indefinitely stalled. Gordon said last week that with the
resignation of Provost William Bevan last summer,
planning for the fund-raising drive has shifted to his
office. "And," the President added, "I've been so busy
on other things that I haven't had much time for the
campaign." Possibly Dr. Gordon could spend less time
poring over every last insignificant detail and criticizing
the News-Letter and more on this essential Presidential
function. Just because Dr. Muller, the recentlyappointed Vice-President, will be assuming his job in
July doesn't mean that Homewood House can't begin
intensifying their fund-raising campaign now.

Acting as an informal advisory body convened by Dean
Benton, the non-existent Temporary Advisory Council
has approved the formation of an Arts and Sciences
Advisory Council(ASAC) to advise the Dean on matters
"that are not within the realm of existing committees."
The ASAC will have the same composition of
